hi and welcome you listening to the x-22

1562 a and today's date is May 7th 2018

let's get into the economic collapse

seeing in the economy we've been talking
about credit we've been talking about
housing we've been talking about
automobile we've been talking about
pretty much everything that is under the
Sun here and we are starting to see
bubbles start to pop and we knew this
was going to happen we knew it was
eventually going to start someplace and
this is going to spread from country to
country from country to country we're
already seeing out in Canada Toronto
they're having a problem home sales in
the Greater Toronto Area Canada's
largest housing market among the most
inflated in the world plunged by 32
percent in April compared to a year ago
now when we look at the stats these are
pretty darn dramatic I mean detached
houses they have dropped by thirty eight
point four percent semi-detached houses
dropped by twenty nine point three
percent town houses down twenty two
point one percent condos down by twenty
six percent sales of homes costing two
million or more collapse by sixty four
percent the market is freezing up at the
top this will spread to the bottom and
we're starting to see the entire housing
bubble pop now think about this for a
second what is happening out in the
market mortgage rates are continually
rising this pushes a lot more people out
of the market and if a lot more people
out of the market you have less traffic
coming to these homes if there's less
traffic coming to these homes you don't
have enough buyers if you don't have
enough buyers the houses stay on the
market longer and longer and longer if
the houses stay on the market longer
longer and longer the house prices come
down and they keep falling this is what
happened back in 2006-2007 this is when
individuals didn't understand what was
going on real estate sales people didn't
understand what was going on because
they were used to bringing bus loads of
people to homes showing it to them and
it was sold the same exact day and then
all of a sudden interest rates started
to rise mortgage rates started to rise
the traffic dried up and they couldn't
get anyone to come to the houses and all
you saw was prices continually dropping
and everyone started to chase the market
because every time you lowered it the
market lowered the price even further
and it kept happening in many many
different areas we are seeing the same
thing happened once again now the
bubbles that were created after 2008
they're all going to start to pop just
like Canada Canada has one of the
biggest housing bubbles we've ever seen
it's bigger than the US and we're
starting to see it's completely falling
apart commercial real estate prices they
peaked in August 2017 at 27 percent
above the crazy peak of the prior bubble
now according to the Green Street
commercial property index the sea PPI we
can see that prices now they're falling
and by April this year the index was
down 1.4 percent from the peak and by
about 1% from April a year ago and we
can see from the graph that if we go
back in time and we look at 2007 2008
2009 we see the commercial property
price index down by negative 10 we are
already at negative 2 and this is April
2018 and it's been dropping since mid
2017 and we're going to the same exact
spot we were during the financial crisis
now we're seeing a lot of economic
indicators showing us that the economy
is completely falling apart we're seeing
bubbles pop
and we're seeing that credit cards they
are at the highest point that we've ever
seen and again a lot of people are
tapped out a lot of people just don't
have enough to you know go along on

are using their credit cards to make

that we have about 1 trillion of credit
card revolving loans a record 1.3
trillion of auto loans and a record 1.5
trillion of student loans now credit
card and auto loans have been
experiencing accelerating delinquencies
and when we look at this we could see
that the big banks aren't the problem
this time it's the small banks they're
seeing a huge amount of credit card
charge offs and it's almost at the point
it was during the crisis now the big
banks they have been pushing this off to

to be hit as hard but we can see what is
happening right now and we can see the
outstanding credit card borrowings
unexpectedly declined by 2.6 billion the
most since the end of 2012 after a drop
of just about 500 million last month now
when we look at the graph and we look at
the revolving consumer credit and

everything is fantastic and then
